text: I was sitting having breakfast with a
couple Somali guys and Tyler Hicks who
works for the New York Times as a
photographer when we heard a huge boom
and the people around the breakfast
table looked at each other and started
calling across town to see what had
happened about 10 or 15 minutes later we
heard another explosion then we feared
the worst a hotel across town maybe two
or three miles away was under attack and
this is one of the signature complex
terrorist attacks that have become quite
common in Mogadishu where a terrorist
group called al-shabaab detonates a
large bomb in front of a target and then
waits a few minutes and detonates a
second bomb
we jumped into a truck an armored truck
and went rushing with an escort of about
5 to 10 gunmen to a hospital what
casualties began streaming in we saw
people badly wounded so blood on the
floors we saw the victims were covered
in fine powder of white concrete from
the explosions where walls had collapsed
on them there were large crowds of
family members who are grieving outside
I spoke to one young Somali journalist a
freelance cameraman who had been warned
not to go to the scene of the bombing
and had went anyway because he said this
was his livelihood and he was lying in a
hospital bed his hands and mittens of
gauze wounds all over his body clearly
in pain and he had been one of the
people who rushed to the first explosion
only to be felled by the second covered
many bombings in Somalia I've been
working here for the past 10 years but
what was really upsetting about this one
is that this country has made great
strides to distance itself from the
violence and chaos of the recent past
and you can feel that there's a real
struggle for the soul of this place for
people who are trying to resume a normal
life
[Music]
Oh
you
